thread.title_full: Brook Lopez flashes potential to be superstar the Nets need | New York Post

author: Tim Bontemps
title: Brook Lopez flashes potential to be superstar the Nets need
text:
AUBURN HILLS, Mich. — If the Nets are going to be a competitive team this season, they’re going to lean heavily on Brook Lopez.
On Thursday night, he showed he’s capable of shouldering the load.
Going up against Detroit’s Andre Drummond, one of the game’s elite young centers, Lopez put on a clinic, finishing with 17 points, nine rebounds and two blocked shots as the Nets came away with a 93-83 preseason win over the Pistons at The Palace of Auburn Hills.
“We played with a lot of confidence,” Lopez said. “We had a lot of energy on the defensive end throughout and we shared the ball well.
“That’s the kind of stuff we’re going to have to bring every night if we’re going to be competitive. We want to be a good team, and those are things we have to count on having every night.”
Lopez is right, but what the Nets are going to need every night to be competitive is for him to play like an All-Star. And Thursday he looked every bit the part.
He may have wound up with a similar stat line to Drummond, who finished with 14 points and 11 rebounds, but there was little doubt who had the bigger impact. Lopez’s mere presence in the pick-and-roll allowed Shane Larkin and Donald Sloan — who split the point-guard minutes with Jarrett Jack (rest) sitting out — to get wherever they wanted on the court.
Each found Lopez multiple times for wide-open mid-range buckets after the defense collapsed on them after they went around one of Lopez’s screens.
“That’s deadly,” Sloan said of running the pick-and-roll with Lopez. “That’s what you want to have out there every time, because you make them dictate what you can do.”
But it wasn’t just offensively where Lopez’s impact was felt. He also played well on defense, forcing Drummond into some tough shots and helping the Nets put together a far better defensive showing than they did in Monday’s loss to Fenerbahce.
“We had a lot of energy,” Lopez said. “We tried to be in the right places, and when we weren’t we recovered by playing hard, and we made up for a lot of mistakes.”
Lopez received a three-year max contract this summer, after the Nets kept him at the trade deadline once Oklahoma City turned down a deal that would have seen the Nets send Lopez to the Thunder for a package built around point guard Reggie Jackson. The Thunder moved Jackson to Detroit as part of a three-team trade instead.
It was a wise deal for the Nets not to make. They wound up getting Thaddeus Young for Kevin Garnett at the deadline in a separate deal. Young and Lopez helped the Nets stretch run to the eighth seed in the East, and both free agents were re-signed this summer to build around.
The Nets re-signed Lopez, in part, with the hope his second half — he posted numbers of 19.7 points, 9.2 rebounds and 1.8 blocks while shooting 52.5 percent from the floor — was proof he was capable of carrying them into contention this season.
Playing against Drummond who, either this month or next summer, will get a max contract of his own, there was no doubt who was better. If the Nets are going to be the competitive team Lopez hopes they can be, they will need that kind of showing from him on a nightly basis.
